name: WordPress
support: Open source (GPLv2 license) supported by a large community and most hosting providers
technology: PHP and MySQL backend; runs on a web server (LAMP stack)
capabilities: Extensive customization through tens of thousands of themes and more than 59,000 plugins; user‑friendly interface; built‑in blogging tools; search‑engine‑friendly architecture; large community and documentation; public REST API
limitations: Can slow down or become unstable when too many plugins are used; requires regular updates and maintenance; third‑party themes and plugins can introduce security vulnerabilities; advanced customizations may require technical knowledge

name: Drupal
support: Open source project with enterprise‑level support from Acquia and a global developer community
technology: PHP running on a web server (Apache or Nginx) with a database such as MySQL, MariaDB, PostgreSQL or SQLite
capabilities: Robust and scalable content modeling and taxonomy system; advanced user roles and access control; multilingual support; strong security hardening; headless/decoupled architecture via RESTful API; high scalability for large and complex websites
limitations: Steep learning curve compared with WordPress; smaller marketplace of themes and modules; requires more server resources; fewer developers and higher development cost

name: Joomla
support: Free open‑source software maintained by The Joomla! Project and its community
technology: PHP application using a MySQL or PostgreSQL database and running on a web server
capabilities: Thousands of extensions and templates; built‑in SEO tools; flexible menu and module system; template override and custom fields for bespoke layouts; built‑in multilingual support and translation management; strong user management with granular permissions; robust security features including two‑factor authentication
limitations: Steeper learning curve than WordPress; smaller extension ecosystem and fewer templates; extension compatibility issues can occur during upgrades; declining market share and smaller developer pool

name: Ghost
support: Open source platform run by the non‑profit Ghost Foundation; offers paid hosting and community support
technology: Built on Node.js; stores content in a database (SQLite by default, MySQL for production) and uses the Handlebars templating language
capabilities: Minimalist editor (Koenig) focused on writing; built‑in support for memberships, newsletters, and subscriptions; fast performance and modern API for headless implementations; content can be published via REST and GraphQL APIs; clean, responsive themes
limitations: Limited theme repository and few free themes; customizing themes requires learning Handlebars and code injection is restricted; fewer plugins and integrations compared with WordPress; self‑hosting requires command‑line installation and a Node.js environment

name: Wix
support: Proprietary website builder offered by Wix.com with hosted plans and customer support
technology: Closed SaaS platform running on Wix’s servers; drag‑and‑drop client built with JavaScript; does not require a separate database
capabilities: Hundreds of professionally designed templates; pixel‑perfect drag‑and‑drop editing; App Market with add‑ons such as e‑commerce, email marketing and booking systems; AI website builder; automatic backups and hosting; Wix Studio for responsive design and custom CSS/JS
limitations: More expensive premium plans; mobile versions often require manual tweaks; slower page loading speeds; cannot change templates without rebuilding the site; limited page depth and a 100‑page limit; closed ecosystem restricts exporting the site
